title: Serhii Plokhy: ‘Our history is full of secrets'
text:
Serhii Plokhy, 63, is a history professor at Harvard University and a leading authority on eastern Europe. His books include Lost Kingdom, The Gates of Europe and Baillie Gifford Prize-winner Chernobyl: History of a Tragedy.

What was your childhood or earliest ambition?
I grew up in Ukraine in the 1960s and 1970s, when it was still part of the Soviet Union. During the space race, I wanted to be an astronaut. I then decided to explore the world behind the Iron Curtain instead and become a foreign correspondent.

Private school or state school? University or straight into work?
There were only state schools in the Soviet Union, but I got into a good one. After school, I improved my social standing by failing university exams and joining the working class. Given that workers in the socialist society were officially a privileged group, in comparison to the intelligentsia, to which my parents belonged, I did pretty well for myself. The next year I entered university.

Who was or still is your mentor?
At the age of 14, I started to write for a youth newspaper in my hometown and met a local journalist who was also a poet, Anatoly Rekubratsky. He was my first guide to the world of literature, culture and writing. I was very lucky to get excellent mentors at every stage of my career, which brought me from Soviet academia to the west.

How physically fit are you?
Not as fit as I want to be, but I am trying. Each new year starts with a new resolution to exercise more. Some years are better than others.

Ambition or talent: which matters more to success?
You need both, but without ambition, talent does not count for much. So I would say ambition.

How politically committed are you?
I am committed to ideas. Freedom and equal opportunity are among those. I try not to commit myself to any group where the right to choose is taken away from me by somebody else. Politics is a team sport that can be quite a challenge, but I try.

What would you like to own that you don't currently possess?
Time. Other than that, a better stationary bike.

What's your biggest extravagance?
I never say no to a visit to Australia.

In what place are you happiest?
In my wife's garden. She is a fantastic gardener, among all the other things that she is great at.

What ambitions do you still have?
To write a book about the past that will change the future.

What drives you on?
The pursuit of the unknown. Deep down, I am a history detective. Our history is full of secrets and the hardest to get to are those that are hidden in the open.

What is the greatest achievement of your life so far?
Learning to read, think and express myself in languages that were originally foreign to me. When I say “languages”, I also mean the cultures behind them. That opened horizons to me that otherwise would be closed.

What do you find most irritating in other people?
When they genuinely believe in things that I know for sure are not true. My training as a historian included a critique of historical sources, and I wish that subject was included in all school curriculums.

If your 20-year-old self could see you now, what would he think?
“Wow! You have seen the world, man!” In my youth, international travel was something you could only dream about.

Which object that you've lost do you wish you still had?
As a child I played with my grandfather's medals from World War II. I do not really know what happened to them, but I feel responsible for their loss.

What is the greatest challenge of our time?
How to save the climate without destroying the environment by another Chernobyl.

Do you believe in an afterlife?
I study the afterlives of people's deeds and ideas. So yes, I believe in that kind of afterlife. Our memories and the history books we read or write are the backbones of the afterlife in that sense of the word.

If you had to rate your satisfaction with your life so far, out of 10, what would you score?
Seven. I will keep working on the remaining three. Those remaining three, I suspect, are on the very top shelf and are the hardest to get.

“Nuclear Folly: A New History of the Cuban Missile Crisis” (Allen Lane) by Serhii Plokhy is out now
